name: Troy's Korean Glazed Chicken Breast with Kimchee Fried Rice
description: Kimchee gives fried rice a nice spicy kick in this chicken recipe perfect for busy weeknights. Serve with a spicy mayo for extra heat. This recipe is made in a Panasonic CIO and appears on an episode of the Dinner Spinner TV Show on The CW!
recipeIngredient: salt and ground black pepper to taste
1 slice fully cooked luncheon meat (such as SPAM®), cubed
1 tablespoon butter, or more to taste
½ cup chopped napa cabbage kimchee
¼ cup chopped pickled carrot and daikon radish
1 tablespoon soy-based liquid seasoning (such as Maggi®)
2 tablespoons gochujang (Korean hot pepper paste), or to taste
1 teaspoon Sriracha hot sauce, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Place chicken breasts on a solid, level surface. Pound with a meat tenderizer to an even thickness; season with salt and pepper and toss with 2 tablespoons peanut oil until evenly coated.

Heat a cast iron or heavy skillet over medium heat. Place chicken in heated skillet and cook until no longer pink in the center, about 4 minutes per side. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 165 degrees F (74 degrees C). Brush barbeque sauce on top of chicken. Cover skillet and cook until chicken is glazed, about 1 minute per side. Transfer chicken to a plate and cover with aluminum foil to keep warm.

(A countertop induction oven can be used in place of the skillet to cook the chicken. Preheat the oven with the grill pan inside on the grill setting. Grill chicken on medium until no longer pink in the center, about 4 minutes per side. Brush barbeque sauce on top of chicken and return to oven; cook until chicken is glazed, about 1 minute per side.)
Wipe skillet with a paper towel. Heat remaining 2 tablespoons peanut oil over medium heat. Add luncheon meat; cook and stir until browned and crisp, 3 to 5 minutes.

Heat butter in a separate skillet over medium heat. Add pickled carrot and daikon, kimchee, and rice; cook and stir until heated through, 1 to 2 minutes. Season rice mixture with liquid seasoning and soy sauce; stir in garlic flakes. Cook and stir until rice is crisp in places, 3 to 5 minutes. Add gochujang and luncheon meat to fried rice and mix well.
Divide fried rice among serving plates. Slice chicken breasts; arrange over rice.
Mix mayonnaise and Sriracha hot sauce together in a small bowl; spoon over chicken. Sprinkle green onion on top.

aggregateRating.itemReviewed: Troy's Korean Glazed Chicken Breast with Kimchee Fried Rice

review.reviewBody: Troy WOW this is a wonderful dish packed full of KAPOW flavor! First and foremost I love the spam. I held a viewing party with both this dish and Jackie's while your show was on and everyone loved your use of luncheon meat. It was nearly the topic of conversation. Also GREAT recipe for kimchi friend rice and love the twist of the pickled daikon and carrots. Pairing it with the perfectly cooked KBBQ sauce basted chicken is ingenious. Awesome job AWESOME show and looking forward to more delicious recipes coming from you! You need to write a cookbook.:)

Made this as written except that there was no skin on my chicken boobs and I didn't know what garlic flakes were so I just used powder. This is really good but I highly recommend using low sodium products where you can and even at that this is not one for those watching their sodium intake. It is not there in taste punching you in the face but it is there for certain. The only thing that would make this recipe better is an egg. Whether it be an over-easy over the top or a scrambled in the rice I think it needs egg. Other than that...perfect!

Wow this was super delicious and flavorful! I did not use the pickled carrot but I did use everything else. Really great combo of flavors and beautiful to boot...I will def be making this one again YUM!!! Thanks for sharing.:)
I frequently make kimchi fried for dinner but hadn't ever thought of topping it with chicken...loved it! Next time I will add a fried egg!

This was good, tasty, and spicy as a Korean kimchi dish should be. But it is not your standard run-of-the-mill fried rice. So don’t be surprised. It is a bit more work than the standard fried rice I normally make, which is typically just whatever is left over in the fridge, but it was worth it to get a little more kimchi into my diet. I’ve been trying to do that for the health effects associated with kimchi. If you’re into spicy Asian food, especially Korean, I think you’ll enjoy it. If you aren’t, tread lightly.?
